section.title: Purpose
section.p: If you want to import a dictionary, using a command typed in your systemâ€™s command area instead of windows might be more convenient.

refsyn.title: Format
refsyn.p: The following syntax diagram describes how you import a dictionary from the Windows command area. Note that lowercase letters in a parameter name are optional and need not be typed.

section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: DICIMP specifies that you want to import a dictionary.
Specifies the name of the SGML file containing the dictionary that you want to import along with the drive and directory where it is located.
Specifies the name of an existing dictionary to which the dictionary specified in FIles is to be imported to. It can be a local or a shared dictionary.

This parameter is particularly useful if the existing dictionary already contains entries. It specifies the following:
REPLACE The entries in the SGML (external) dictionary file replace the entries in the existing (internal) dictionary.
IGNORE Ignores the entries in the SGML (external) dictionary.
COMBINE Combines the entries in the SGML (external) dictionary file with the entries in the existing (internal) dictionary. This is the default. That means if nothing is specified, the system assumes that you want to combine the dictionary entries.

password specifies the password of the dictionary to which the SGML file is to be imported (if this dictionary is write-protected). If the dictionary is write-protected and no password is entered, processing stops.

If you specify this parameter, you are not prompted with any message window. If you do not specify this parameter, a message window pops up whenever an error occurs or when the task has successfully completed.

section.note: You can type the commands in uppercase, lowercase, or in mixed-case letters. You may not use any wildcard characters, such as an asterisk (*).

example.title: Examples
example.p: The following example shows how to import a dictionary using the OTMBATCH command.
In this example, the dictionary file mymemo.sgm, which is in external (SGML) format, is imported to the existing dictionary newmemo. The entries in mymemo.sgm replace the entries in newmemo.
